conclusion: Understanding how shadows change when the light source moves backwards involves considering the position and intensity of the light source, and the relative positions of the objects and the surface.
The light source is positioned above the objects, casting shadows A, B, C, and D on the ground.
The objects are: A birdcage (A), a red box (B), a black lampshade (C), and a decorative cross (D).
When the light source moves backwards, it will be further away from the objects and the surface.
As the light source moves further away, the shadows will become smaller and the intensity of the light will decrease, making the shadows less distinct.
The birdcage is on the left side of the image.
As the light source moves backwards, the shadow of the birdcage will become smaller and less intense. The shape and position will remain similar, but the size will decrease.
The red box is in the top left corner.
The shadow of the red box will also become smaller and less intense. The shape and position will remain similar, but the size will decrease.
The black lampshade is in the top right corner.
The shadow of the black lampshade will become smaller and less intense. The shape and position will remain similar, but the size will decrease.
The decorative cross is in the bottom right corner.
The shadow of the decorative cross will become smaller and less intense. The shape and position will remain similar, but the size will decrease.
When the light source moves backwards, all the shadows (A, B, C, and D) will become smaller and less intense. The shapes and positions will remain similar, but the size will decrease.
